tips.verbsQuestion: What's the best way to learn verbs?
tips.verbsAnswer: Use Learn mode and ask for conjugation tables. Practice all 6 persons (I, you, he/she, we, you all, they) together.
tips.partnerQuestion: How do I practice with my partner?
tips.partnerAnswer: Use phrases you've learned in daily conversations. Even simple greetings count! Create challenges for each other in the Play section.
tips.progressAnswer: 15-20 minutes of daily practice works wonders. Consistency beats cramming!
tips.forgetQuestion: What if I forget a word?
tips.forgetAnswer: Play games - they automatically resurface words you're struggling with. The spaced repetition helps lock them in.

section1.headline: Skip the boring stuff. Learn the words that matter. The ones that make them smile.
section1.subhead: The ones they only use with people they love.
section1.copy: Their inside jokes. Their family phrases. The way they say 'I love you' when nobody's listening.
section1.underline: The way they say 'I love you' when nobody's listening

section2.headline: There's a conversation you're not part of. Yet.
section2.copy: The jokes you smile through without getting. The family stories that lose something in translation. Time to actually get it.

section3.headline: You're not learning a language. You're learning them.
section3.copy: Their words. Their jokes. Their way of roasting you lovingly. Built for people who are in it for love, not grades.
section3.underline: Built for people who are in it for love

section4.headline: Learning their language = flirting with extra steps.
section4.copy: This isn't school. There's no test. Just you, showing up for them in a whole new way. Pretty romantic, honestly.

section5.headline: The moment you make their family laugh? Chef's kiss.
section5.copy: The first time you actually get the joke. The first 'I love you' in their language that sounds just right. The moment their mom starts speaking directly to you in their language. It's coming.

section6.headline: Learn together. Love together. Laugh together.
section6.copy: They'll send you words that matter. Challenge you to games. Roast your pronunciation (lovingly). This isn't studying alone‚Äîit's building your own little world together.
section6.underline: building your own little world together

section1.headline: They love you. Now help them love your language too.
section1.copy: Your words. Your jokes. The way you curse when you stub your toe. There's a whole you they haven't met yet‚Äîa whole new you. Let them in.

section2.headline: You've tried explaining. They've tried nodding. Let's fix this.
section2.copy: The things you say when you're really happy. Or really annoyed. The words that feel like home. They want to understand all of you‚Äînot just the translated version.

section3.headline: Every word you share is a bridge.
section3.copy: Share words. Create challenges. Celebrate wins together. The app handles the boring stuff‚Äîyou just get to be the fun one.
section3.underline: you just get to be the fun one

section4.headline: Send a word. Start a game. Watch them grow.
section4.copy: Challenge them to your mom's favorite phrase. Quiz them before dinner. Celebrate when they nail it. This is couples time disguised as learning‚Äîand it's actually fun.
section4.underline: This is couples time disguised as learning

section5.headline: The moment they surprise you with a phrase you never taught them? Magic.
section5.copy: When they crack a joke and your family actually laughs. When your mom starts speaking directly to them in your language. When they drop a phrase that makes your jaw drop. You made that happen.

section6.headline: Teach together. Play together. Fall deeper in love.
section6.copy: This is how you share who you really are. Word by word. Game by game. Laugh by laugh. And they get to fall in love with all of it.
section6.underline: And they get to fall in love with all of it

context2.subtext: Some things translate better when learned.
